sentence: Has Chipotle Mexican Grill (CMG) found the right person to lead the company and its shareholders out of what has been three years' worth of misery?
The market seems to think so.
Judging by the the 16% spike in CMG shares, investors are applauding the arrival of Brian Niccol, former CEO of rival Taco Bell, who will now assume the same position at Chipotle.
The strong applause might have something to do with the fact that under Niccol’s leadership, Taco Bell was seen a highly innovative.
Aside from launching breakfast, Niccol oversaw a massive transition towards mobile ordering and payments at Taco Bell’s 7,000 restaurants.

In the press release, announcing the hire, Steve Ellis, Chipotle’s founder, who will become executive chairman, said, “Niccol will bring fresh energy and leadership to drive excellence across every aspect of our business.” Adding, "His expertise in digital technologies, restaurant operations and branding make him a perfect fit for Chipotle as we seek to enhance our customer experience, drive sales growth and make our brand more relevant.”

On Wednesday, CMG shares, which had fallen to a five-year low to under $250, rose on more than four time its volume to a high of $292.
Prior to those gains, the stock had plunged almost 70% in two years.
The company’s meteoric rise and its subsequent fall has been well documented, stemming from issues related to multiple airborne illnesses at its restaurants that had gotten consumers sick.
In that vein, Niccol’s arrival, particular for his marketing expertise, should immediately pay dividends, particularly from the standpoint of restoring Chipotle’s brand image.
He’s been credited for executing one of the most impressive performances in the fast food sector.
He seems ready to do the same for Chipotle.
"I am very excited to be joining Chipotle at this pivotal time in its history.
I have tremendous respect for the Chipotle brand and its powerful purpose,” Niccol said.

“At Chipotle's core is delicious food, which I will look to pair up with consistently great customer experiences.”

Prior to joining Taco Bell, he’s held leadership roles at Procter & Gamble (PG) and Pizza Hut, which like Taco Bell is also a Yum!
Brands (YUM).
He comes with a strong pedigree.
But while investors cheered his arrival, Wall Street analysts have seemingly taken a wait-and-see attitude.
As of this writing, no major investment firm has gone out on a limb to adjust its rating or price target.
The company suffered two downgrades following its most-recent earnings report, including a Sell call from Stifel analysts.
In other words, Niccol’s most-difficult job might be earning the Street’s confidence, which can only be achieved by getting customers to come back into the restaurants.
For now, at least, investors are nonetheless optimistic that if anyone can make this happen, it’s Niccol.
The views and opinions expressed herein are the views and opinions of the author and do not necessarily reflect those of Nasdaq, Inc.
